Problem:
Imagine a system where we want to study heat transfer in a rod governed by the heat equation \\(u_t = k u_{xx}\\) where \\(k\\) is the thermal diffusivity of the material. We analyze the scenario where at time \\( t = 0 \\), a temperature distribution \\( u(x, 0) = u_0(x) \\) is initially applied, and then see its evolution or the effects of interventions.

If an intervention by adding a heat source described by a delta function at a point \\( x_0 \\) occurs at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), will the temperature profile \\( u(x, T) \\) for \\( T > t_1 \\) be solely dependent on the thermal diffusivity \\( k \\) and not on the location or intensity of the delta function?
Explanation: The addition of a heat source changes both the location and shape of the temperature distribution. The profile at any later time \\( T > t_1 \\) not only depends on the thermal diffusivity \\( k \\) but also critically on the location and intensity of the delta function heat source due to the localized increase in temperature.
